title: Chinese Embassy renovates an auditorium of the BiH Cinematheque
description: In December 2016, Chinese Embassy hired a construction company to restore the auditorium of the BiH Cinematheque in Bosnia and Herzegovina.  On December 11, 2017, Ambassador Chen Bo attended the ceremony of opening the renovated cinema hall of the public institution Cinematheque BiH. Director of the Cinematheque BiH Mrs Filipović, President of the Association Bosnian-Chinese Friendship Mr Borić, wife of the director of the movie “Valter Defends Sarajevo” Hajrudin Krvavac, Mrs Ešrefa Krvavac and many other distinguished individuals from culture, art and film industry in BiH attended the event.
staff_comments: The Chinese name for the project is 波黑电影资料馆放映厅重建项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Embassy renovates an auditorium of the BiH Cinematheque

# Description
In December 2016, Chinese Embassy hired a construction company to restore the auditorium of the BiH Cinematheque in Bosnia and Herzegovina.  On December 11, 2017, Ambassador Chen Bo attended the ceremony of opening the renovated cinema hall of the public institution Cinematheque BiH. Director of the Cinematheque BiH Mrs Filipović, President of the Association Bosnian-Chinese Friendship Mr Borić, wife of the director of the movie “Valter Defends Sarajevo” Hajrudin Krvavac, Mrs Ešrefa Krvavac and many other distinguished individuals from culture, art and film industry in BiH attended the event.
justification: Project involves renovation of a cultural facility with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Renovation of auditorium in Cinematheque, cultural/art focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides scholarships to 34 students from Botswana
description: In 2016, the Chinese Ministry of Education provided 34 students from Botswana scholarships to study abroad in China, while it has been reported that 30 more students will benefit from more scholarships provided by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. An official departing ceremony for the 34 students was held in August 2016, with the Botswana Assistant Minister of Education and Skills development Moiseraela Goya, Chinese Ambassador to Botswana Zheng Zhuqiang, and the Botswana Secretary in the Ministry of Presidential Affairs and Public Administration Mogomotsi Kaboyamodimo, wishing the students farewell and elaborating on the educational relationship between Botswana and China. The 34 scholarships from the Chinese Ministry of Education have already been provided, however the status of the 30 from the Chinese Ministry of Commerce is unknown, as well as the duration and cost of the scholarships.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides scholarships to 34 students from Botswana

# Description
In 2016, the Chinese Ministry of Education provided 34 students from Botswana scholarships to study abroad in China, while it has been reported that 30 more students will benefit from more scholarships provided by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. An official departing ceremony for the 34 students was held in August 2016, with the Botswana Assistant Minister of Education and Skills development Moiseraela Goya, Chinese Ambassador to Botswana Zheng Zhuqiang, and the Botswana Secretary in the Ministry of Presidential Affairs and Public Administration Mogomotsi Kaboyamodimo, wishing the students farewell and elaborating on the educational relationship between Botswana and China. The 34 scholarships from the Chinese Ministry of Education have already been provided, however the status of the 30 from the Chinese Ministry of Commerce is unknown, as well as the duration and cost of the scholarships.
justification: Scholarship program focused on education with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Scholarships for students from Botswana to study in China, education sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides grant worth P125 million for Kazungula Primary School Construction Project
description: In mid-2016, Botswana’s Ministry of Finance and Development Planning and China’s Ministry of Commerce of China prepared and reviewed a draft grant agreement and exchange of notes for the Kazungula Primary School Construction Project. Then, on August 24, 2018, both parties signed and exchange of notes for the project. A grant agreement was signed in December 2016. The Chinese Government committed RMB 80 million for the project.   The project would involve the construction of a primary school in the village of Kazungula — 8 km east of the town of Kasane — in Botswana’s North-West District. The school would include teaching blocks, an administrative building, a dining hall, living quarters for principal and teachers, a gatehouse, equipment, and auxiliary facilities. The Government of Botswana agreed to assist in the implementation of the project by obtaining work permits for Chinese workers and aiding in the implementation of infrastructure networks throughout the school. On March 27, 2019, a project implementation agreement was signed and a groundbreaking ceremony was held on October 15, 2019. The finished elementary school was anticipated to accommodate 560 students. As of October 30, 2020, the school was still under construction.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 博卡尊古拉小学项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant worth P125 million for Kazungula Primary School Construction Project

# Description
In mid-2016, Botswana’s Ministry of Finance and Development Planning and China’s Ministry of Commerce of China prepared and reviewed a draft grant agreement and exchange of notes for the Kazungula Primary School Construction Project. Then, on August 24, 2018, both parties signed and exchange of notes for the project. A grant agreement was signed in December 2016. The Chinese Government committed RMB 80 million for the project.   The project would involve the construction of a primary school in the village of Kazungula — 8 km east of the town of Kasane — in Botswana’s North-West District. The school would include teaching blocks, an administrative building, a dining hall, living quarters for principal and teachers, a gatehouse, equipment, and auxiliary facilities. The Government of Botswana agreed to assist in the implementation of the project by obtaining work permits for Chinese workers and aiding in the implementation of infrastructure networks throughout the school. On March 27, 2019, a project implementation agreement was signed and a groundbreaking ceremony was held on October 15, 2019. The finished elementary school was anticipated to accommodate 560 students. As of October 30, 2020, the school was still under construction.
justification: Project is focused on education infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of primary school with teaching blocks, administrative building, and auxiliary facilities

title: China National People's Congress donates computers and office supples to Botswana’s National Assembly
description: On September 27, 2016, the ambassador of Botswana Zheng Zhuqiang and the Botswana National Assembly Speaker Kokowe attended the handover ceremony of a small batch of official supplies materials, including Lenovo laptops, to Botswana Parliament as a gift from China National People's Congress. Information cannot be found on any other details or value of supplies. Meanwhile, it was the end of Zheng Zhuqiang's term as Botswana Ambassador.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China National People's Congress donates computers and office supples to Botswana’s National Assembly

# Description
On September 27, 2016, the ambassador of Botswana Zheng Zhuqiang and the Botswana National Assembly Speaker Kokowe attended the handover ceremony of a small batch of official supplies materials, including Lenovo laptops, to Botswana Parliament as a gift from China National People's Congress. Information cannot be found on any other details or value of supplies. Meanwhile, it was the end of Zheng Zhuqiang's term as Botswana Ambassador.
justification: Project involves donation of office equipment without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of computers and office supplies to government institution, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Government donates computer labs to Kubang Primary School in Botswana in Maun
description: On August 26, 2016, Chinese Embassy donated computer labs to Kubung Primary School located in Maun, Botswana. The donation ceremony was attended by Li Nan, the Political Counselor of the Embassy of Botswana, and Mokgweetsi Masisi, Vice President of Botswana. Kubung Elementary School was built by the Chinese government. It opened in 2011 and was officially "adopted" by the Chinese Embassy in Botswana by 2013.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government donates computer labs to Kubang Primary School in Botswana in Maun

# Description
On August 26, 2016, Chinese Embassy donated computer labs to Kubung Primary School located in Maun, Botswana. The donation ceremony was attended by Li Nan, the Political Counselor of the Embassy of Botswana, and Mokgweetsi Masisi, Vice President of Botswana. Kubung Elementary School was built by the Chinese government. It opened in 2011 and was officially "adopted" by the Chinese Embassy in Botswana by 2013.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of computer labs to primary school, education sector focus

title: Chinese Government funds Gymnastics Technical Cooperation Project
description: In March 2016, China sent a group of experts to Botswana to help train Botswana citizens in gymnastics to celebrate the 50th Independence Anniversary of Botswana. The project was termed the Botswana 50th Anniversary Celebration Group Gymnastics Technical Cooperation Project. The first performance exhibition was held on August 28, 2016 at the Botswana National Stadium and a separate anniversary ceremony was held in September 2016. Chinese instructors trained more than 4000 teachers and students. The project was implemented by China Sports International Co., Ltd in cooperation with the Botswana Ministry of Youth, Sports, and Culture.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government funds Gymnastics Technical Cooperation Project

# Description
In March 2016, China sent a group of experts to Botswana to help train Botswana citizens in gymnastics to celebrate the 50th Independence Anniversary of Botswana. The project was termed the Botswana 50th Anniversary Celebration Group Gymnastics Technical Cooperation Project. The first performance exhibition was held on August 28, 2016 at the Botswana National Stadium and a separate anniversary ceremony was held in September 2016. Chinese instructors trained more than 4000 teachers and students. The project was implemented by China Sports International Co., Ltd in cooperation with the Botswana Ministry of Youth, Sports, and Culture.
justification: Project focuses on cultural exchange and sports training without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Gymnastics training program, cultural celebration event, no energy or infrastructure components

title: China Eximbank provides $1 billion loan to Petrobras Global Trading B.V. to fund capital projects
description: Following a visit by Premier Li Keqiang to Brazil, China Eximbank and Petróleo Brasileiro S.A. (Petrobras) signed an agreement regarding a potential $2 billion loan to fund capital projects. Then, on October 24, 2016, China Eximbank issued a $1 billion line of credit to PGT BV with a final maturity date of May 23, 2019. $900 million of the $1 billion credit line was drawn down by the borrower in May 2018. PGT BV was expected to withdraw an additional $100 million from the credit line in May 2019.  The borrower ultimately drew down the entire credit line, but the precise date of the final drawn down is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $1 billion loan to Petrobras Global Trading B.V. to fund capital projects

# Description
Following a visit by Premier Li Keqiang to Brazil, China Eximbank and Petróleo Brasileiro S.A. (Petrobras) signed an agreement regarding a potential $2 billion loan to fund capital projects. Then, on October 24, 2016, China Eximbank issued a $1 billion line of credit to PGT BV with a final maturity date of May 23, 2019. $900 million of the $1 billion credit line was drawn down by the borrower in May 2018. PGT BV was expected to withdraw an additional $100 million from the credit line in May 2019.  The borrower ultimately drew down the entire credit line, but the precise date of the final drawn down is unknown.
justification: Loan to Petrobras for capital projects, which is primarily an oil and gas company
evidence: Funding provided to Petrobras Global Trading B.V., a subsidiary of Petróleo Brasileiro S.A., for capital projects

title: CDB provides first, $5 billion loan tranche to Petrobras to help it meet its repayment obligations (Linked to Project ID#53067 and ID#59384)
description: On February 26, 2016, Petroleo Brasileiro S.A. (Petrobras) and China Development Bank (CDB) signed a term sheet for a $10 billion line of credit (captured via Project ID#53067). The line of credit was to be disbursed in two, $5 billion tranches (with 10 year maturities and 4.2325% interest rates) and used by the borrower to address its maturing debt obligations. Petrobras and CDB signed a $5 billion agreement for the first loan tranche on December 15, 2016 (captured via Project ID#53068). This loan tranche disbursed on December 22, 2016. Then, on December 14, 2017,  Petrobras and CDB signed a $5 billion agreement for the second loan tranche (captured via Project ID#59384), which fully disbursed in December 2017 and January 2018.   As a source of collateral for the first loan tranche, Petrobras signed oil-supply contracts with three Chinese companies [China National United Oil Corporation (a subsidiary of CNPC), China Zhenhua Oil Co. Ltd. (a subsidiary of NORINCO), and Chemchina Petrochemical Co. Ltd (a subsidiary of ChemChina)] on December 15, 2016. Under each contract, Petrobras agreed to sell 100,000 barrels of oil per day for 10 years at market prices. As a source of collateral for the second loan tranche, Petrobras signed an oil-supply contract with UNIPEC Asia — Sinopec’s (subsidiary) trading company — and agreed to provide 100,000 barrels per day for 10 years at market prices. Petrobras reportedly repaid a small portion of the $10 billion debt between 2016 and 2018. However, by the end of 2019, it had repaid $8 billion (including a $5 billion repayment on December 16, 2019).
staff_comments: 1. Most of China’s oil-backed loan agreements involve a bank, an oil company, and a trading firm. An oil company in the borrower country must sell a certain number of barrels during a specific period, and payments for the oil are sent directly to the bank. Therefore, the borrower uses the proceeds of oil sales to meet its loan repayment obligations. 2. Multiple sources indicate that the first tranche and the second tranche fully disbursed. The first tranche was reportedly provided in two payments: a $3.5 billion payment and a $1.5 billion payment. The second tranche was reportedly provided in a $3 billion payment (on December 14, 2017) and a $2 billion payment (on January 26, 2018).3. The loan's interest rate (4.2325%) is recorded in the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (DRS). See https://www.dropbox.com/s/ab8qt4n6jijcbhd/IDS_Average%20interest%20on%20new%20external%20debt%20commitments.xlsx?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/2sw4f7gluxa52fk/DRS%20Official%20Commitments%20from%20China%20Through%202021.xlsx?dl=0
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
CDB provides first, $5 billion loan tranche to Petrobras to help it meet its repayment obligations (Linked to Project ID#53067 and ID#59384)

# Description
On February 26, 2016, Petroleo Brasileiro S.A. (Petrobras) and China Development Bank (CDB) signed a term sheet for a $10 billion line of credit (captured via Project ID#53067). The line of credit was to be disbursed in two, $5 billion tranches (with 10 year maturities and 4.2325% interest rates) and used by the borrower to address its maturing debt obligations. Petrobras and CDB signed a $5 billion agreement for the first loan tranche on December 15, 2016 (captured via Project ID#53068). This loan tranche disbursed on December 22, 2016. Then, on December 14, 2017,  Petrobras and CDB signed a $5 billion agreement for the second loan tranche (captured via Project ID#59384), which fully disbursed in December 2017 and January 2018.   As a source of collateral for the first loan tranche, Petrobras signed oil-supply contracts with three Chinese companies [China National United Oil Corporation (a subsidiary of CNPC), China Zhenhua Oil Co. Ltd. (a subsidiary of NORINCO), and Chemchina Petrochemical Co. Ltd (a subsidiary of ChemChina)] on December 15, 2016. Under each contract, Petrobras agreed to sell 100,000 barrels of oil per day for 10 years at market prices. As a source of collateral for the second loan tranche, Petrobras signed an oil-supply contract with UNIPEC Asia — Sinopec’s (subsidiary) trading company — and agreed to provide 100,000 barrels per day for 10 years at market prices. Petrobras reportedly repaid a small portion of the $10 billion debt between 2016 and 2018. However, by the end of 2019, it had repaid $8 billion (including a $5 billion repayment on December 16, 2019).
justification: Loan directly supports oil production and supply contracts, reinforcing fossil fuel dependency
evidence: Oil-supply contracts as collateral, 100,000 barrels per day for 10 years, Petrobras as borrower

title: Bank of China loans R$ 6,310,000 for the Belo Monte Transmissora de Energia S.A [#59898 and #59891]
description: In 2016, the Bank of China loaned for 6,125,000 Brazilian Reals to Eletronorte (an electricity a generation and transmission subsidiary of Eletrobras) for the Belo Monte Transmissora de Energia S.A., which is a special purpose vehicle created to construct transmissions lines from the Belo Monte dam on the Xingu River in the state of Para. According to the SEC, the disbursed amount was 6,310,000 Brazilian Reals. The transaction amount has been recorded as such.  The transmission line will have 2,100 kilometers and will cross four states: Pará, Tocantins, Goiás, and Minas Gerais. It begins at the Xingu Substation, located approximately 17 kilometers from the Belo Monte Hydropower Dam, in the municipality of Anapu in Para Sate, and extends to the Estreito Substation, located in the municipality of Ibiraci, in Minas Gerais, close to the border with São Paulo State. The estimated construction cost is R $5.1 billion (US $1.6 billion) and the projected start of operations is early 2018.   State Grid won the bid for the construction of the first transmission line in February 2014, forming a consortium called Belo Monte Transmissão de Energia (BMTE). State Grid retained control with 51 percent, whereas two minority partners are controlled by Eletrobras: Eletronorte (24.5 percent) and Furnas (24.4 percent).   The converting stations have completed the earthworks, and civil works are underway. The assembly of structures is in progress, according to the Agência Nacional de Energia Elétrica (ANEEL) and the agency responsible for evaluating the safety and continuity of Brazil’s electricity supply. As of April 2017, the degree of fulfillment of the contract was 67 percent for physical development and 87 percent for general development. As of 2018, the project was nearing completion and operation.  According to the World Bank PPI, State Grid Corporation of China provided 316.8 million USD worth of equity, giving it 51% ownership of the project.
staff_comments: Coded as Vague OF because concessionality is unclear.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Bank of China loans R$ 6,310,000 for the Belo Monte Transmissora de Energia S.A [#59898 and #59891]

# Description
In 2016, the Bank of China loaned for 6,125,000 Brazilian Reals to Eletronorte (an electricity a generation and transmission subsidiary of Eletrobras) for the Belo Monte Transmissora de Energia S.A., which is a special purpose vehicle created to construct transmissions lines from the Belo Monte dam on the Xingu River in the state of Para. According to the SEC, the disbursed amount was 6,310,000 Brazilian Reals. The transaction amount has been recorded as such.  The transmission line will have 2,100 kilometers and will cross four states: Pará, Tocantins, Goiás, and Minas Gerais. It begins at the Xingu Substation, located approximately 17 kilometers from the Belo Monte Hydropower Dam, in the municipality of Anapu in Para Sate, and extends to the Estreito Substation, located in the municipality of Ibiraci, in Minas Gerais, close to the border with São Paulo State. The estimated construction cost is R $5.1 billion (US $1.6 billion) and the projected start of operations is early 2018.   State Grid won the bid for the construction of the first transmission line in February 2014, forming a consortium called Belo Monte Transmissão de Energia (BMTE). State Grid retained control with 51 percent, whereas two minority partners are controlled by Eletrobras: Eletronorte (24.5 percent) and Furnas (24.4 percent).   The converting stations have completed the earthworks, and civil works are underway. The assembly of structures is in progress, according to the Agência Nacional de Energia Elétrica (ANEEL) and the agency responsible for evaluating the safety and continuity of Brazil’s electricity supply. As of April 2017, the degree of fulfillment of the contract was 67 percent for physical development and 87 percent for general development. As of 2018, the project was nearing completion and operation.  According to the World Bank PPI, State Grid Corporation of China provided 316.8 million USD worth of equity, giving it 51% ownership of the project.
justification: Primary purpose is transmission infrastructure for hydropower, which has mixed environmental impacts
evidence: Transmission lines from Belo Monte dam, 2,100 km length, connecting hydropower to grid

title: China Construction Bank loans R$ 96,894,000 for the Belo Monte Transmissora de Energia S.A  [linked to #59863 and #59898]
description: In 2016, the China Construction Bank loaned 93,100,000 Brazilian Reals to Eletronorte (an electricity a generation and transmission subsidiary of Eletrobras) for the Belo Monte Transmissora de Energia S.A., which is a special purpose vehicle created to construct transmissions lines from the Belo Monte dam on the Xingu River in the state of Para, to the Brazilian Southeast. According to the SEC, the disbursed amount was 96,894,000 Brazilian Reals. The transaction amount has been recorded as such.   The transmission line will have 2,100 kilometers and will cross four states: Pará, Tocantins, Goiás, and Minas Gerais. It begins at the Xingu Substation, located approximately 17 kilometers from the Belo Monte Hydropower Dam, in the municipality of Anapu in Para Sate, and extends to the Estreito Substation, located in the municipality of Ibiraci, in Minas Gerais, close to the border with São Paulo State. The estimated construction cost is R $5.1 billion (US $1.6 billion) and the projected start of operations is early 2018.   State Grid won the bid for the construction of the first transmission line in February 2014, forming a consortium called Belo Monte Transmissão de Energia (BMTE). State Grid retained control with 51 percent, whereas two minority partners are controlled by Eletrobras: Eletronorte (24.5 percent) and Furnas (24.4 percent).   The converting stations have completed the earthworks, and civil works are already underway. The assembly of structures is in progress, according to the Agência Nacional de Energia Elétrica (ANEEL) and the agency responsible for evaluating the safety and continuity of Brazil’s electricity supply. As of April 2017, the degree of fulfillment of the contract was 67 percent for physical development and 87 percent for general development. However, problems were reported in some parts of the work. According to Costa (2017), the Chinese contractor SEPCO1, responsible for sections 1 and 2 of the project, had reached 20 percent and 57 percent of the planned work in early 2017, respectively. In the other 6 sections, the project was nearly 78% complete.   According to the World Bank PPI, State Grid Corporation of China provided 316.8 million USD worth of equity, giving it 51% ownership of the project.
staff_comments: Coded as Vague OF because concessionality is unclear.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Construction Bank loans R$ 96,894,000 for the Belo Monte Transmissora de Energia S.A  [linked to #59863 and #59898]

# Description
In 2016, the China Construction Bank loaned 93,100,000 Brazilian Reals to Eletronorte (an electricity a generation and transmission subsidiary of Eletrobras) for the Belo Monte Transmissora de Energia S.A., which is a special purpose vehicle created to construct transmissions lines from the Belo Monte dam on the Xingu River in the state of Para, to the Brazilian Southeast. According to the SEC, the disbursed amount was 96,894,000 Brazilian Reals. The transaction amount has been recorded as such.   The transmission line will have 2,100 kilometers and will cross four states: Pará, Tocantins, Goiás, and Minas Gerais. It begins at the Xingu Substation, located approximately 17 kilometers from the Belo Monte Hydropower Dam, in the municipality of Anapu in Para Sate, and extends to the Estreito Substation, located in the municipality of Ibiraci, in Minas Gerais, close to the border with São Paulo State. The estimated construction cost is R $5.1 billion (US $1.6 billion) and the projected start of operations is early 2018.   State Grid won the bid for the construction of the first transmission line in February 2014, forming a consortium called Belo Monte Transmissão de Energia (BMTE). State Grid retained control with 51 percent, whereas two minority partners are controlled by Eletrobras: Eletronorte (24.5 percent) and Furnas (24.4 percent).   The converting stations have completed the earthworks, and civil works are already underway. The assembly of structures is in progress, according to the Agência Nacional de Energia Elétrica (ANEEL) and the agency responsible for evaluating the safety and continuity of Brazil’s electricity supply. As of April 2017, the degree of fulfillment of the contract was 67 percent for physical development and 87 percent for general development. However, problems were reported in some parts of the work. According to Costa (2017), the Chinese contractor SEPCO1, responsible for sections 1 and 2 of the project, had reached 20 percent and 57 percent of the planned work in early 2017, respectively. In the other 6 sections, the project was nearly 78% complete.   According to the World Bank PPI, State Grid Corporation of China provided 316.8 million USD worth of equity, giving it 51% ownership of the project.
justification: Primary purpose is transmission infrastructure for hydropower, which has complex environmental implications
evidence: Transmission lines from Belo Monte dam, 2,100 km length, connecting hydropower to grid
